question: Question_A_17
statement:
The matrix

\[P = \left[\begin{array}{cc} 4/5 & -2/5 \\ -2/5 & 1/5 \end{array}\right]\]

represents projection onto a line in 2D. Write this line in the form
\emph{y = mx} with \emph{m} determined.
sols:
All points on the line y=mx are given by {[}x0,mx0{]}=x0{[}1,m{]}. If we
have a general point in space {[}x,y{]} then the projection matrix P
should map the point {[}x,y{]} to x0{[}1,m{]}. Since this projection
must hold for all points, it certainly must hold for the basis vectors.
Therefore we try the vector {[}1,0{]}. Since we have,

\[P=\begin{bmatrix}
4/5 & -2/5\\
-2/5 & 1/5
\end{bmatrix}\]

then

\[P\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
4/5 & -2/5\\
-2/5 & 1/5
\end{bmatrix}
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\0
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
4/5\\
-2/5
\end{bmatrix}\]

which of course is just the first column of the transformation matrix
(recall this is exactly how we form transformation matrices). We can
write,

\[\begin{bmatrix}
4/5\\
-2/5
\end{bmatrix}
=
4/5\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1/2
\end{bmatrix}\]

which in the form x0{[}1,m{]} tells us that x0=4/5 and m=-1/2. Therefore
the slope of the line is -1/2. We can then write that the line is
y=-1/2x. To check our answer we could use the second basis vector
{[}0,1{]} which would produce the second column of the matrix and once
again we'd conclude the slope is -1/2.

To begin with, since \emph{P} projects on a line, the vector \emph{Pv}
is on the line for any vector \emph{v}.

Let \emph{(x\textsubscript{0},y\textsubscript{0})} be a vector on the
line that \emph{P} projects onto. Projecting a vector that is already on
the line onto the line, does not change the vector. In mathematical
notation, this means that
$P \begin{bmatrix} x_0 \\ y_0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} x_0 \\ y_0 \end{bmatrix}$
and hence \emph{(x\textsubscript{0},y\textsubscript{0})} is an
eigenvector with eigenvalue 1.

To find this eigenvector, find the nullspace of

\[P-I = \begin{bmatrix}
-1/5 & -2/5 \\ -2/5 & -4/5
\end{bmatrix}\]

Row reducing the matrix above yields

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}\] and hence \emph{(x\textsubscript{0},y\textsubscript{0})
= (-2,1)} is a vector on the line that \emph{P} projects onto. Plugging
this into the equation of the line, \emph{y = mx} yields \emph{1 =
m(-2)} or $m = -\frac12$
hints:
Recall that a transformation matrix applies to all vectors including the
basis vector.

For an alternative solution: What does the projection do to a vector
that is on the line we are looking for? What do we call vectors with
this property?
